Topic.Title: DID YHOO CONCEAL THIS ONGOING LITIGATION?

Message.Msg: Really, do people use printed phone books anymore? No! Not even in Mexico. You'd be surprised as the usuage is around 60% in central MN, heard it from a Yellow Pages district manager herself, a few months ago. The Twin Cities metro is 30% I think, which is more normal IMO. That being said Yellow Pages, Dex One, Supermedia offer far more than that. The offer print ads, online ads, online websites, SEO(search engine optimization) and do it through Google, Bing and Yahoo. Yahoo handles the big corporations but those 3rd parties get the mom and pop businesses. I remember RIMM was sued for a patent violation that could have crippled the company and that was settled for $455-500M or something with royalties...this, a non-patent situation by a small subsidiary will not be worth billions IMO. I say $100M+ max. As for the share price that could have some more whipsaw action if Yahoo buys back more stock. If you watch the stock movement, it always seems to recover and end the day flat. I do think people will be looking to take profits from its straight run.

Yea, it's the same thing, just incredibly awkward. YHOO probably just had some programmers around that were Marissa Mayers butt buddies and couldn't fire them, so they were tasked with doing something completely useless, like rewriting the code to the yahoo mbs.

Message.Title: Process of Civil Law in Mexico
Message.Msg: Civil Law in Mexico... it is by far, a less litigious society than its neighbors to the north. The rule here is that it is far better to negotiate than litigate. Here’s why. The Court Procedures in Mexico are very different. In the U.S. and Canada, the plaintiff’s lawyer files a complaint and the defendant’s lawyer files a response. The two attorneys go through the process of "discovery" and then the case is argued before a judge (and jury) using evidence and witnesses. A decision is made and “awards” are made which can be significant, including costs, damages, special damages and punitive damages. In Mexico, the plaintiff files a complaint providing written evidence with supporting documents and statements from witnesses. The defendant files a response, again in writing, with supporting documentation and witness statements. The judge reviews the submissions, asks for more evidence if he deems it necessary, and then renders a decision. There is no discovery process and lawyers are not allowed to be present when either party or witnesses are called in to make statements. Based on the decision, awards are made for damages but they are much smaller. There are no special or punitive damages and each party pays their own fees and costs. Litigation is expensive, a long process and judgments are often difficult to enforce, even against a solvent defendant. Judgments can be contested in a separate “Amparo” proceeding which can take several years. An “Interlocutory Appeal” can be lodged during the proceeding which will also lengthen the process (and the cost). Civil Law in Mexico... it is by far, a less litigious society than its neighbors to the north. The rule here is that it is far better to negotiate than litigate. Here’s why. The Court Procedures in Mexico are very different. In the U.S. and Canada, the plaintiff’s lawyer files a complaint and the defendant’s lawyer files a response. The two attorneys go through the process of "discovery" and then the case is argued before a judge (and jury) using evidence and witnesses. A decision is made and “awards” are made which can be significant, including costs, damages, special damages and punitive damages. In Mexico, the plaintiff files a complaint providing written evidence with supporting documents and statements from witnesses. The defendant files a response, again in writing, with supporting documentation and witness statements. The judge reviews the submissions, asks for more evidence if he deems it necessary, and then renders a decision. There is no discovery process and lawyers are not allowed to be present when either party or witnesses are called in to make statements. Based on the decision, awards are made for damages but they are much smaller. There are no special or punitive damages and each party pays their own fees and costs. Litigation is expensive, a long process and judgments are often difficult to enforce, even against a solvent defendant. Judgments can be contested in a separate “Amparo” proceeding which can take several years. An “Interlocutory Appeal” can be lodged during the proceeding which will also lengthen the process (and the cost).

Topic.Title: Tiger Global also likes Potential Buyout Candidate, Yahoo!

Message.Msg: If that is true then the market is wrong - if the market is wrong then this run up may not be based upon reality - if Yahoo sells an asset then it still has the same asset - if yahoo spends the cash on share buybacks then they are stating that the money is best used buying their own shares and not growing the company - in fact they are downsizing. If you read the best investment analysis you will find that share buybacks are the worst possible use of cash unless the company has no better ways to use it. Cisco buys back shares at a lower cash rate than they use cash to buy companies - in fact every comapny does - do you really think that Google is deserving a lower PE than YHOO? I woulds like to know where Yahoo will grow...how it will be done....when it will be done....how much the bottom line will benefit from the growth...e very other company can tell you....right now you are trusting big hedge funds to be looking out for YOU - they are not. They will cover their shares with puts and will sell their holdings as fast as they bought them - and as secretly....at themoment all of the buybacks do is pad the pockets of the recently hired execs who have millions of shares in options....note - Yahoo ISSUES shares when they issue options and then they reduce shares by buying them back - in effect Yahoo is buying up their own options. You make money ONLY when you sell at a profit..

Message.Title: Monday may be an opportunity to go long if you missed it
Message.Msg: I'm in yhoo and the last week was pretty lackluster after a decent run. Perhaps some consolidation in the stock was going on as I expect there to be a slight 1.5 to 2% selloff in the open based upon the initial ruling in Mexico. I believe that was for 2.7B It is no doubt a large sum but let us not forget the due process/legal process is quite different in other countries than our own. I'm in Jan 17.5 and 19 calls but do believe Monday would be a nice day to average down. I'm convinced the opportunity should last for several days. As for why Meyer isnt saying anything-she doesnt need to at this point. Things will be fine for this very solid company with great prospects and solid leadership. I would not worry although we will see a little blip for a bit so shorts that got in at 19.15/19.16 you'll make out decent but dont gloat too much as we'll get you within the month for sure and definitely by the turn of the new year with ease.

Topic.Title: Article from Forbes posted on Alibaba's investor relations site...

Message.Msg: Yahoo Finance has what i believe as the greatest worth of the Yahoo! Inc. core. But if you look to the right side of the page you will see a white void. They are not displaying ads in these white voids. Empty page space is a problem. I would guess that they do not have a abundance of ads at the moment as the page veiws are certainly high here with what i believe to be a high rate of engagment time per messsage board.That makes the page space prime, as to why they do not utilize it is a mystery.

Topic.Title: I do think the CEO needs to come out before the market opens with guidance

Message.Title: Buy All you can in $ 18 range--You will be very pleased
Message.Msg: Yahoo is grossly undervalued Conclusion A lot of people like to compare the Internet to the automobile industry in its early stages. In both situations, we saw enormous growth. While the automobile industry slowed down, there was still a lot of profit to go around. The biggest players traded the top spot throughout the years and decades. The same will happen with Internet-related companies, such as Yahoo, Google, Amazon, and Facebook. It’s difficult to see Yahoo competing with some of these names, but they have plenty of firepower (i.e., cash) at their disposal. All they need now is a little innovation, especially with mobile and social. Yahoo’s long-term prospects are superb. Therefore, Yahoo is a long-term OUTPERFORM.

Topic.Title: Article from Forbes posted on Alibaba's investor relations site...

Message.Msg: Not a clue on the big surprise. Would not even hazard a guess. Agent "99" might know. If you will note there are posts here that are obviously not generated by th eposted but are copy and pasted. However, the origin of the content is specified / credited. That content is actually protected under copyright to someone. That is a copyright violation unless the originator of the content gives rights to copy the content or gets paid. And the change of the messege boards may have been influenced due to those violations. Just my thoughts.
